title: 469-B
statement: B. Chat Onlinetime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutLittle X and Little Z are good friends. They always chat online. But both of them have schedules.Little Z has fixed schedule. He always online at any moment of time betweena1andb1, betweena2andb2, ..., betweenapandbp(all borders inclusive). But the schedule of Little X is quite strange, it depends on the time when he gets up. If he gets up at time0, he will be online at any moment of time betweenc1andd1, betweenc2andd2, ..., betweencqanddq(all borders inclusive). But if he gets up at timet, these segments will be shifted byt. They become[ci+t,di+t](for alli).If at a moment of time, both Little X and Little Z are online simultaneosly, they can chat online happily. You know that Little X can get up at an integer moment of time betweenlandr(both borders inclusive). Also you know that Little X wants to get up at the moment of time, that is suitable for chatting with Little Z (they must have at least one common moment of time in schedules). How many integer moments of time from the segment[l,r]suit for that?InputThe first line contains four space-separated integersp,q,l,r(1 ≤p,q≤ 50; 0 ≤l≤r≤ 1000).Each of the nextplines contains two space-separated integersai,bi(0 ≤ai<bi≤ 1000). Each of the nextqlines contains two space-separated integerscj,dj(0 ≤cj<dj≤ 1000).It's guaranteed thatbi<ai+ 1anddj<cj+ 1for all validiandj.OutputOutput a single integer — the number of moments of time from the segment[l,r]which suit for online conversation.ExamplesInput1 1 0 42 30 1Output3Input2 3 0 2015 1723 261 47 1115 17Output20

processed.result:
There are two people with online schedules. 

Person 1 is always online during the following time intervals:

* $[a_1, b_1]$
* $[a_2, b_2]$
* ...
* $[a_p, b_p]$

Person 2's online time depends on when they wake up. If they wake up at time 0, they are online during:

* $[c_1, d_1]$
* $[c_2, d_2]$
* ...
* $[c_q, d_q]$

If Person 2 wakes up at time $t$, their online intervals shift by $t$ to become:

* $[c_i + t, d_i + t]$ for all $i$.

Person 2 wants to wake up at a time between $l$ and $r$ (inclusive) so that they can chat with Person 1 at least once.  

How many times between $l$ and $r$ can Person 2 wake up to ensure they can chat with Person 1? 


Input:

* The first line contains four space-separated integers: $p$, $q$, $l$, $r$ ($1 \le p, q \le 50$; $0 \le l \le r \le 1000$).
* The next $p$ lines each contain two space-separated integers: $a_i$, $b_i$ ($0 \le a_i < b_i \le 1000$).
* The next $q$ lines each contain two space-separated integers: $c_j$, $d_j$ ($0 \le c_j < d_j \le 1000$).

Output:

* A single integer representing the number of times Person 2 can wake up to chat with Person 1.

You are given two sets of time intervals. One set represents when a person is always online, and the other set represents when a person is online depending on when they wake up.  Find how many times between two given points can the two people be online at the same time.
